detect_operator(image_minus, -).
detect_operator(image_multiply, *).
detect_operator(image_divide, /).
detect_all([N], [N2]) :- 
 detect_number(N, N2).
detect_all([N,O|T], [N2,O2|T2]) :- 
 detect_number(N, N2), 
 detect_operator(O, O2), 
 detect_all(T, T2).
almost_equal(X, Y) :- 
 ground(Y), 
 abs(X - Y) < 0.0001.
almost_equal(X, Y) :- 
 var(Y), 
 Y is float(X).
expression(Images, Result) :- 
 detect_all(Images, Symbols), 
 parse(Symbols, Result).
parse([N], R) :- 
 almost_equal(N, R).
parse([N1, +, N2 | T], R) :- 
    almost_equal(N1 + N2, Temp),
    parse([Temp | T], R).
parse([N1, -, N2 | T], R) :- 
    almost_equal(N1 - N2, Temp),
    parse([Temp | T], R).
parse([N1, *, N2 | T], R) :- 
    almost_equal(N1 * N2, Temp),
    parse([Temp | T], R).
parse([N1, /, N2 | T], R) :- 
    almost_equal(N1 / N2, Temp),
    parse([Temp | T], R).
query(expression([image_2, image_divide, image_3, image_plus, image_3, image_minus, image_2, image_multiply, image_7], X)).
final_report: The generated code modifies the parsing logic of the original code, particularly in how it handles arithmetic operations. The original code uses a recursive approach to parse expressions with proper operator precedence, while the generated code simplifies this by immediately evaluating pairs of numbers with their operators. This change leads to incorrect results due to incorrect operator precedence handling. For example, the generated code incorrectly evaluates '2 / (3 + 3) - 2 * 7' as 11.666... instead of the correct -10.333...
